content.title: The Role Of Data In Advancing Sustainable Energy And Equity
content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

Energy data holds transformative potential for driving sustainable energy transitions and fostering equity. By capturing the complexities of energy access, consumption patterns, and environmental footprints, data offers a lens to measure progress, uncover disparities, and inform decisions. Its role extends far beyond technical metrics, becoming a foundation for inclusive policies and impactful interventions. In this lesson, we explore how energy data enables a nuanced understanding of impact across environmental, social, and economic dimensions, setting the stage for actionable insights.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy equity metrics
concepts.body: Energy equity metrics are measures used to assess the fairness and accessibility of energy resources and services across different communities, ensuring that all populations have equal access to affordable, reliable, and sustainable energy.

concepts.title: ethical data practices
concepts.body: Ethical data practices refer to the responsible and fair handling of data, ensuring privacy, consent, transparency, and accountability in data collection, usage, and sharing.

concepts.title: multi-tier frameworks
concepts.body: Multi-tier frameworks are structured systems that organize processes or components into different levels or layers, each with specific roles and responsibilities, often used to enhance efficiency, scalability, and manageability in complex projects or systems.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Tracking progress and measuring impact

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Evaluating the outcomes of energy policies and initiatives demands robust impact measurement. Energy data serves as both a diagnostic tool and a strategic resource, enabling stakeholders to link interventions with tangible changes in emissions, resource use, and community well-being. Through granular analysis, data can illuminate patterns of success and reveal areas needing refinement.
Social and Economic Impact Analysis

Energy data provides critical insights into the intersection of equity and opportunity. Metrics like energy access, affordability, and reliability reveal disparities in marginalized communities and highlight opportunities for targeted improvements. For example, tracking energy access among rural households or employment shifts in green energy sectors unveils trends in inclusion and economic empowerment. Such analysis ensures interventions align with equitable development objectives, bridging the gap between policy intent and lived experiences.
Environmental Impact Assessment

Environmental impacts of energy systems span from emissions and resource depletion to ecosystem disruption. Data enables stakeholders to quantify these effects through methodologies like Life Cycle Assessment, which evaluates every stage—from resource extraction to disposal. Tracking emissions, pollutant concentrations, and water use offers actionable insights into mitigating harmful outcomes. Data-driven strategies empower governments and organizations to prioritize actions that align with sustainability goals, ensuring environmental stewardship in energy planning.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A. UNDP’s Energy Moonshot Tracker

content.text: UNDP’s 2022 – 2025 Strategic Plan has embedded energy access as one of four critical moonshots for development. The energy transition will take place everyone in the world. To be just and sustainable, it must involve achieving both universal access to modern energy services and moving towards clean energy supplies. All five of the other signature solutions, on poverty, governance, resilience, the environment, and gender equality, have close ties to energy. Working with partners to support their efforts on delivering energy access and scale up the UNDP’s impact is essential to achieve the energy moonshot. UNDP’s comparative advantage lies in its ability to leverage its integrator mandate and maximize partnerships across the UN and other partners and can offer an integral development focus combining multiple development benefits that are enabled by clean energy; and reaching those “left behind” and hard-to-reach areas. Delivering independent technical advice using our in-country presence and knowledge of the local context and stakeholders will address unmet demand. The UNDP energy portfolio encompasses a variety of interventions dedicated to supporting numerous energy-related activities with a focus on development. These interventions directly contribute to promoting energy access and fostering a just energy transition through investments in clean energy, the utilization of renewable energy technologies, energy efficiency, clean cooking solutions, and showcasing local initiatives aimed at reducing fossil fuel dependence in both household and commercial activities. The UNDP energy portfolio extends its reach to support e-mobility initiatives, contributing to a comprehensive and sustainable approach to energy development.

This include either directly interventions with the implementation of on-grid and off-grid renewable electricity initiatives (such as biomass electricity generation, solar mini-grids, and micro-hydro projects) and the distribution of solar home systems, including productive use appliances, or indirectly promoting sustainable energy for development transformations supporting policy development, capacity building, and/or removing barriers to private and public investment. The portfolio also addresses the critical aspect of clean cooking, providing policy support to governments and facilitating capacity development for both public and private sectors.

To strengthen UNDP's internal monitoring mechanisms on collective progress towards the energy moonshot, the Tracker analysis aims to identify the number of beneficiaries, both direct and indirect, for all UNDP energy projects active under the UNDP Strategic Plan for the period 2022-2025. The Sustainable Energy Hub is leading an effort to track the portfolio of UNDP energy-related projects to develop a picture of where investment is being directed and what benefits are being addressed globally. This is the first time that we have a detailed mapping on Vertical and Non-Vertical Fund projects. A methodology has been developed to convert project outputs into a quantification of indirect and direct beneficiaries. The portfolio of project outputs has been collated from inputs from the 130 UNDP Country Offices (COs), and an effort is underway to clean up this data to prepare it for conversion based on the proposed methodology. This operation is essential to: monitor the achievement of UNDP energy moonshot counting the number of beneficiaries, direct and indirect, but also to support UNDP Country Offices (COs) and UNDP as whole to have access to global data in the field of energy for development. link the work on UNDP with partners for a collective effort to achieve the energy moonshot. align the energy moonshot with the other moonshot and identify areas of connection to work together with an integrated approach.

The Energy Moonshot Tracker aims to strengthen UNDP's internal monitoring mechanisms on collective progress toward the energy moonshot. This tool measures the impact of all UNDP energy projects active under the UNDP Strategic Plan for the period 2022–2025. The impact measure will be in the terms of the number of beneficiaries, both direct and indirect.

In collaboration with all 130 COs, we identify 118 countries that have active energy related projects, 936 outputs have been compiled from 330 projects. Based on analysis of all UNDP projects active during the Strategic Plan 2022-2025, the projected outputs indicate a potential over direct access to clean energy for 55M people, productive use of energy for 34M people million beneficiaries. Evaluating the impact on indirect beneficiaries’ entails projecting the potential ripple effect of energy interventions. These projections include a "conservative scenario" with 100 M indirect beneficiaries and an "optimistic scenario" with 150 M indirect beneficiaries.
89M Beneficiaries

It is important to note that these numbers are estimated based on the target values of project outputs and/or data provided by UNDP Country Office surveys. The Energy Moonshot Tracker—UNDP’s internal data and analytics tool—serves as a critical resource for UNDP COs and regional teams, ensuring permanent access to up-to-date project insights. However, achievement results will require further analysis and validation. UNDP is driving numerous initiatives to advance its energy moonshot. Its active portfolio includes Vertical Fund (VF) and Non-Vertical Fund (non-VF) energy projects. Vertical Funds are earmarked financing mechanisms for specific thematic areas (e.g., climate, biodiversity), while Non-Vertical Funds represent flexible, non-earmarked resources. This analysis encompasses both VF and non-VF projects, including flagship initiatives such as: AMP (Africa Minigrids Programme): A initiative expanding decentralized renewable energy access in rural Africa through solar minigrids. PUDC (Programme d’Urgence de Développement Communautaire): A community-driven program in West Africa accelerating electrification and clean energy access. Solar4Health: A global initiative powering healthcare facilities with solar energy to strengthen health systems. Preliminary findings reveal insights into project outputs, particularly when comparing budgets to beneficiary numbers.

UNDP’s energy activities span diverse areas: from renewable electrification, solar home systems, clean cooking, energy efficiency, and e-mobility, to de-risking facilities, financial mechanisms, and policy support for governments. These efforts include capacity development for both public and private sectors. Beyond energy and SDG7 (Affordable and Clean Energy), UNDP’s Sustainable Energy Hub (SEH) employs a systems approach to energy transitions, recognizing their potential to accelerate progress across multiple SDGs—including health (SDG3), education (SDG4), gender equality (SDG5), decent jobs (SDG8), and sustainable cities (SDG11). This underscores the need for a portfolio approach, shifting from fragmented, project-based interventions to integrated programmatic and policy-driven strategies. Such systemic solutions aim to deliver transformative, lasting impact by addressing interconnected challenges holistically.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Ensuring Equity in Energy Access Through Inclusive Data Collection

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Disparities in energy access not only impede economic development but also hinder educational opportunities and exacerbate social inequalities. Stakeholders can leverage data to both identify barriers to energy access and craft strategies to overcome them . Comprehensive energy data identify underserved communities and the factors contributing to energy poverty, such as infrastructure limitations, affordability issues, and geographic remoteness. Through detailed data analysis, policymakers and development organizations can design targeted interventions and allocate resources effectively to expand energy access to marginalized populations.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. World Bank's Multi-Tier Framework

content.text: Multi-Tier Framework for Measuring Access to Electricity

Achieving equity in energy access requires tools that capture the intricate realities of diverse communities. The World Bank’s Multi-Tier Framework (MTF) offers a transformative approach to energy access measurement, challenging traditional methods that overlook the complexity of energy inequities. This framework enables a nuanced understanding of energy services, helping policymakers and practitioners to address barriers that perpetuate exclusion and inequality. Developed by the World Bank’s Energy Sector Management Assistance Program in 2015, the MTF moves beyond binary classifications. It introduces a system of tiers that assess access across multiple dimensions, such as capacity, reliability, affordability, quality, formality, and health and safety. This approach provides a detailed portrait of energy access, revealing the multifaceted challenges faced by communities at various stages of energy service provision. For instance, electricity access becomes more than the presence of infrastructure; it includes factors like service reliability and affordability, which often dictate whether energy is genuinely accessible. Similarly, access to modern cooking solutions is evaluated through attributes like fuel availability, stove efficiency, and safety, shedding light on barriers that hinder widespread adoption.
Multi-Tier Framework for Measuring Access to Cooking Solutions

he MTF demonstrates the power of detailed, multidimensional data to uncover inequities in energy systems. It evaluates modern cooking solutions across attributes such as cooking exposure, stove efficiency, convenience, safety, affordability, and fuel availability. These metrics offer insights into systemic barriers that disproportionately affect vulnerable groups: Cooking Exposure quantifies health risks tied to pollutant levels, a burden borne heavily by women and children in many households. Convenience highlights the time and labor costs of fuel collection, often shouldered by women in low-income or rural areas. Affordability underscores the financial challenges preventing households from adopting cleaner energy solutions. This level of detail not only informs policy but also ensures interventions are better aligned with the lived experiences of those affected by energy poverty.

Effective use of the MTF hinges on inclusive data collection. Data must reflect the diverse realities of marginalized groups—rural households, indigenous communities, and informal settlements—whose energy challenges often remain invisible in traditional surveys. Combining quantitative measures with qualitative insights allows for a richer understanding of energy access, making it possible to address structural inequities more effectively. By prioritizing inclusivity, data collection efforts can move beyond technical measurements to reflect broader socio-economic and cultural dimensions of energy access. This approach ensures that policies and programs are informed by the perspectives of those most impacted by energy transitions. The MTF is more than a measurement tool; it is an instrument for reshaping how energy planning is conducted. It highlights overlooked dimensions of energy systems, prompting governments and organizations to rethink priorities. For instance, insights from the MTF might redirect resources from infrastructure expansion to affordability mechanisms, reliability improvements, or targeted subsidies for clean cooking solutions. This framework also facilitates cross-sectoral collaboration by linking energy access to health, education, and economic development. Its multidimensional perspective underscores the interconnected nature of energy access and broader development outcomes, fostering more integrated and effective strategies.

Incorporating the MTF into national and global energy planning efforts is essential for advancing equity in energy transitions. The framework challenges conventional approaches, offering a pathway to more inclusive and equitable energy systems. By embracing its multidimensional insights, stakeholders can address the root causes of energy inequities and create interventions that resonate with the needs of diverse communities. This shift requires an ongoing commitment to refining methodologies, engaging underrepresented voices, and using data as a catalyst for systemic change. The MTF exemplifies how a thoughtful and inclusive approach to energy planning can drive progress toward equity, ensuring that energy transitions contribute to both sustainability and social justice.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Transparency and Accountability in Data Reporting

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Transparency and accountability are essential in energy data reporting, as they ensure information is credible, actionable, and fosters trust among stakeholders. Transparent reporting involves clearly communicating the risks and opportunities associated with various energy pathways, offering a structured basis for informed decisions, and creating a foundation for measurable progress. It also establishes a framework for collaboration, encouraging the exchange of information and perspectives, particularly when exploring potential solutions to energy challenges.

Effective transparency in reporting delivers numerous benefits. First, it builds trust by mitigating suspicions of bias or manipulation and demonstrating the integrity of the data. Comprehensive and reproducible reporting practices ensure that stakeholders can verify findings and use the data confidently. Without such transparency, stakeholders may question the objectivity of the data, potentially undermining trust and engagement (Junne et al., 2019). Second, transparent reporting enables peer-to-peer learning and benchmarking, helping organizations and governments compare their energy frameworks against regional or global counterparts. It serves as a valuable resource for investors and developers, providing the data needed to perform due diligence and attract capital. Transparent practices also create opportunities to exchange lessons and insights across different regions facing similar challenges, enhancing collective problem-solving (Banarjee, 2017). Finally, transparency underpins evidence-based policymaking. By providing clear and traceable data, it supports the development and evaluation of regulations and policies aimed at advancing sustainable energy. A lack of transparent reporting can erode confidence in the policy environment, making it difficult to assess progress or adapt strategies effectively. To strengthen the role of transparency and accountability in energy data reporting, stakeholders must prioritize practices that emphasize reproducibility, inclusivity, and clarity, ensuring that data serves as a reliable tool for driving progress in the energy transition.
Framework for Energy Statistics

Energy statistics have a major role in comprehensive reports on progress toward sustainability goals, and thus statistical analysis needs to follow a methodological framework. The International Recommendations on Energy Statistics (IRES) from the United Nations Statistical Commission provides data compilers with a complete set of recommendations covering all aspects of the statistical production process, from basic concepts, definitions, and classifications to data sources, data compilation strategies, energy balances, data quality, and statistical dissemination. This framework can be utilized by all countries, irrespective of the level of development of their statistical systems. This report benefited from the feedback from members of the Oslo Group on Energy Statistics, which included national representatives of various countries, as well as representatives of the International Energy Agency (IEA), Eurostat, and the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Statistical and administrative data source

The generation of energy data is based on a collection from two main sources: Statistical data sources that provide data collected exclusively for statistical purposes from censuses and/or sample surveys; and administrative data sources that provide data created originally for purposes other than the production of statistical data. The typical statistical data sources for compiling energy statistics are surveys of the units in the population under consideration. The surveys are done either by enumerating all the units in the population (census) or a subset of representative units scientifically selected from the population (sample survey). Publicly controlled administrative data sources are provided officially by government institutions to gain public and check & balance trust through transparency and accountability.

Data may be collected by diverse governmental agencies in response to legislation and/or regulations to: (i) monitor activities related to production and consumption of energy; (ii) enable regulatory activities and audit actions; (iii) assess outcomes of government policies, programs and initiatives. Each regulation/legislation (or related group of regulations/legislations) usually results in a register of the entities (enterprises, households, etc.) bound by that regulation/legislation and in data resulting from application of the regulation/legislation. The register and related data are referred to collectively as administrative data. The data originating from administrative sources can be effectively used in compiling energy statistics.
Privacy concerns and ethical considerations related to data collection and sharing

The collection and sharing of data in the energy sector face growing scrutiny due to tensions between safeguarding individual privacy and leveraging data for effective policy-making. As the risks of exposing personally identifiable information (PII) increase, the need for robust safeguards and ethical frameworks becomes paramount.

In many countries, legislation mandates a distinction between identifiable and non-identifiable data. In the United States, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) defines PII as information that can uniquely identify an individual, such as names, Social Security numbers, or biometric records. However, the U.S. lacks a comprehensive, unified definition of PII, leading to varied interpretations across jurisdictions and states. In contrast, the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) takes a broader approach, defining personal data as "any information which is related to an identified or identifiable natural person." This includes direct identifiers like names as well as quasi-identifiers such as location data or online behavior. Despite these frameworks, public trust is often eroded by inconsistent enforcement, opaque data practices, and high-profile breaches. For example, energy usage data—when aggregated with other datasets—can inadvertently reveal sensitive household behaviors, such as occupancy patterns or appliance usage. Without strict anonymization protocols, informed consent, and transparent governance, communities may resist sharing data, undermining policy efforts.

Beyond privacy, ethical considerations are critical in ensuring data processes adhere to high standards of accountability and fairness. Energy data, whether gathered through surveys or administrative records, should be collected voluntarily and only for its intended purpose. Ethical practices require minimizing harm to communities, avoiding biases in data design, and ensuring informed consent. However, ethical gaps persist. Data divides are widening as wealthier nations and institutions prioritize insights that align with their financial or geopolitical interests. Some intergovernmental organizations (IGOs) restrict data reporting to member states or funders, excluding low-income countries that lack resources to commission targeted analyses. For instance, energy access datasets in sub-Saharan Africa often rely on outdated or incomplete surveys due to funding constraints, while high-income countries benefit from real-time smart meter data. This inequity perpetuates systemic biases, slowing progress toward SDG7 (universal energy access) and deepening global disparities.

Tools like the Data Ethics Canvas, developed by the UK’s Open Data Institute, provide practical frameworks for identifying and managing ethical risks. For example, UK Power Networks, a leading electricity distributor, used the Canvas to embed ethical standards into its data strategy, prioritizing privacy-by-design and stakeholder transparency. Such efforts demonstrate how institutions can rebuild trust through accountability. Ultimately, privacy and ethical practices are essential to maintain public trust, support equitable policy-making, and harness data for societal benefit. However, achieving this requires addressing systemic barriers—from inconsistent regulations to funding-driven data prioritization—that currently exclude marginalized communities and undermine global energy equity.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Monitoring progress towards sustainable energy goals is key.
takeaways.description: Monitoring the evolution of key indicators, such as the renewable energy share in total final energy consumption (e.g., indicator 7.2.1), provides vital insights into the progress toward sustainable energy goals. This data-driven approach enhances countries' ability to plan scenarios effectively in line with achieving global energy targets by 2030.

takeaways.title: Economic growth and energy policies are critical.
takeaways.description: Data-driven analysis offers valuable evidence regarding the economic impacts of different energy policies, including effects on GDP, employment rates, and trade balances. Energy modellling, encompassing various methodologies such as econometric analysis and technology-rich accounting frameworks, serves as a crucial component in informing energy policy formulation.

takeaways.title: We must always be evaluating the environmental impact of sustainable energy development.
takeaways.description: Integration of data on sustainable energy development with environmental datasets enables comprehensive assessments of environmental impacts and facilitates the monitoring of changes over time.
